The CharacterString is a set of characters of which a string is comprised.
Classification information can be provided by several ways:
by a simple class string;
EXAMPLE 1 A string 'company' specifies that an is a company.
NOTE For the permissive list of values, this notion will be used.
by the definition of an explicit class;
EXAMPLE 2 A class with 'company' classifies all objects which are companies. The object allows for additional information like a description.
by the definition of an external class;
EXAMPLE 3 The information, that an is classified as a company, is defined in an which is referenced by and .
by the definition of an external owl class.
EXAMPLE 4 The information, that an is classified as a company, is defined in an which is referenced by an URI.
The ClassString is a string specifying a .
The CoordinateTypeEnum type specifies the values that characterizes the type of a cordinate system.
the type of coordinate system is cartesian.
the type of coordinate system is cylindrical.
the type of coordinate system is spherical.
the type of coordinate system is polar.
the type of coordinate system is linear.
The DateTimeString is a string to specify a date and an optional time of day. The representation of date and time shall be according to ISO 8601.
The DescriptorSet specifies a set of two or more objects.
An EvaluationResultEnum type lists the possible result values of an evaluation.
the evaluation has failed.
the evaluation has passed.
the evaluation result is neither 'fail' nor 'pass'.
An EvaluationStatusEnum type lists the status values of an evaluation.
the evaluation is not valid.
the evaluation can not be concluded.
the evaluation is still to be performed.
the evaluation is valid.
The IdentifierSet specifies a set of two or more objects.
The IdentifierString is a string used to define an .
The Language is a proxy specifying a language.
A LengthMeasure is the value of a distance.
The MatingTypeEnum specifies the kind of mating, i.e., how the items shall be mated together.
an attachment of two or more items that are screwed together using screws, bolt nuts, and washers.
an attachment of two or more items established by soldering or brazing.
an attachment of two or more items established by using a clamp at one common outer border.
an attachment of two or more items established by pressing these items together and stamping texture at the point of contact.
an attachment of two or more items established by a clip (e.g. fixing the inner door panel at the inner door plate).
an attachment of two or more items established by a clip (e.g. fixing the inner door panel at the inner door plate).
an attachment of two or more items by crimping a projected length of one part over the edge of the other part.
an attachment of two or more items where foam is injected into a cavity to establish the connection.
an attachment of two items established by adhesion material.
an attachment of two or more items that are welded together using a laser technique.
an attachment of two or more items obtained by forces resulting from the selected size tolerances.
an attachment of two or more items that are riveted together at a certain spot using a rivet.
an attachment of two or more items that are sewn together.
an attachment of two or more items that are welded together at a certain welding spot.
an attachment of two or more items at a certain spot using a nail or a wire stitch to establish the connection.
an attachment of two or more items by welding together with one weld bead.
an attachment of two or more items by soldering together with one solder bead.
an attachment of two or more items by welding together using friction.
The PropertyDefinitionString is a string to specify the kind of a property. The PropertyDefinitionString corresponds in the more detailed property concept to the attribute of .
’noise absorption’, ’power consumption’ or 'colour' are examples for the PropertyDefinitionString.
A ProxyString is a string to specify a .
The SpecificationExpressionOperationEnum type is an enumeration of the Boolean operators 'and', 'or', 'oneof', and 'not'.
These operators can be used in a .
In the case where these operators are used in a , evaluation of the operation is done in the context of a product. The result depends on the operators in the expression and on whether that product, that may be represented within an instance of , possesses or not the specifications that are referred to in the .
a logical operation that is true if every operand is true.
a logical operation that is true if at least one of the operands is true.
a logical operation that is true if only one of the operands is true.
a logical operation that is true if none of the operands is true.
A StockCategoryEnum is an enumeration of type.
a ANISOTROPIC_MATERIAL is a type of whose properties are different in each material direction.
a BRAIDED_ASSEMBLY is a type of
a DISCONTINUOUS_FIBER_ASSEMBLY is a type of that is a collection of discontinuous fibers suspended in a homogeneous material (matrix). In general, the length of the fibers are relatively the same within a detail. The orientation of the fibers is usually random.
When a ply is made from a DISCONTINUOUS_FIBER_ASSEMBLY, the DISCONTINUOUS_FIBER_ASSEMBLY is in the form of a sheet or is applied as a constant thickness coating to the area defined by the ply. Some resin transfer molded (RTM) parts, where the mixture of short fibers and matrix is injected into a mold, can be viewed as a DISCONTINUOUS_FIBER_ASSEMBLY.
DISCONTINUOUS_FIBER_ASSEMBLY
a FILAMENT_ASSEMBLY is a type of that is a collection of yarns or tows combined together in some manner and frequently embedded in a matrix of homogenous material. The FILAMENT_ASSEMBLY is usually measured by weight and sometimes length to describe the amount needed for a .
When a ply is made from a FILAMENT_ASSEMBLY it is usually referred to as woven or non-woven fabric such as broad goods and tape. A ply can also be made from such things as a collection of tows or yarn provided the tow or yarn lay flat in the area described by the ply and they are a single thickness that does not stack on top of one another or overlap. The thickness or cross-sectional area of a FILAMENT_ASSEMBLY is specified in the ply or that is made from the stock material. These are usually specified in cured thickness or cross-sectional area. Woven and non-woven fabric, individual tows, yarns, and roving are types of filament assemblies (see next figure ).
FILAMENT_ASSEMBLY
a ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL is a type of that is made up of a single uniform internal structure.
When ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL such as resin plays the role of a matrix within other stock materials, the ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL is combined with filaments to make filament assemblies and with fibers to make discontinuous fiber assemblies. When ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL such as stabilizers, foaming and film adhesives are applied separately from other stock materials, a ply references the ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL to provide placement and thickness. When ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL are such things as blocks of material that can be described by a fixed shape, they can either be considered or remain ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL if they are not going to be combined with other to produce a composite part. The latter could take on the part types of extrusion, plate, bar, casting, forging, and tubing. Resins, stabilizers, foaming and film adhesives are types of ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL. Also metals in general can be considered ISOTROPIC_MATERIAL.
a STOCK_CORE is a type of that is processed to be placed within a laminate and play a role in enhancing the stiffness of the laminate.
Honeycomb, phenolic block, and corrugation are types of STOCK_CORE.
a WOVEN_ASSEMBLY is a type of .
A TransitionCodeEnum is an enumeration that conveys the continuity properties of a motion along a . The continuity referred to is geometric, not parametric continuity.
the motion segments join, and their tangent vectors are parallel and have the same direction at the joint; equality of derivatives is not required.
the motion segments join, their tangent vectors are parallel and in the same direction, and their curvatures are equal at the joint; equality of derivatives is not required.
the motion segments join, but no condition on their tangents is implied.
the motion segments do not join; the motion is interrupted.
The TranslatedStringSet specifies a set of objects.
is a string to specify an Uniform Resource Identifier (normally an http:// URL).
An Activity is an identification of the occurrence of an action that has taken place, is taking place, or is expected to take place in the future. The procedure executed during that Activity is identified with the that is referred to by the chosenMethod attribute. Change, distilling, design, a process to drill a hole, and a task such as training someone, are examples of activities.
The items that are affected by an Activity, for example as input or output, may be identified within an instance of .
the identifier or set of identifiers for the Activity.
The value of this attribute need not be specified. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in Fundamental concepts and assumptions.
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the Activity.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the Activity.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the activityType specifies the purpose of the Activity.
The following values shall be used for activityType:
'amendment': An Activity to add information to product data;
'analysis': An Activity to determine the behaviour of an element under certain physical circumstances;
'cancellation': An Activity to delete an element from the bill of material or to cancel the whole bill of material;
'delivery change': An Activity to change the delivery schedule of an element;
'design change': An Activity to change the design of an item or an assembly; this might include changes to the geometry or to properties of the object;
'design': An Activity concerning the development of a design of an item;
'mock-up creation': An Activity to create an experimental model or replica of an item;
'prototype building': An Activity to manufacture a preliminary version of an item;
'rectification': An Activity to correct the data, documentation or structure associated with an item;
'restructuring': An Activity to create a new structure or position within a bill of material without changing the data associated with the items in the bill of material;
'spare part creation': An Activity to design a spare part or to classify an item as a spare part;
'stop notice': An Activity to stop the manufacturing process of an item;
'testing': An Activity to test an item;
'work definition': An Activity to manage several sub-activities related to this Activity by an with a of value 'decomposition'.
the date when the Activity actually finished. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the date when the Activity actually started. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the that specifies the procedure selected to carry out the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the set of objects that are affected by the result of the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the date when the Activity is or was supposed to be finished. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the date when the Activity is or was supposed to be started. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the or that requested the Activity and the date the request was submitted. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the set of objects that are resolved by the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the status specifies the level of completion of the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified. The value 'open' is an example for status.
The values and sequence of status are company specific.
the set of objects that carry out the work. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the object that controls the Activity.
An ActivityAssignment is a an association of an with product or activity data. It characterizes the role of the concepts represented with these data with respect to the activity.
This entity should not be used to represent the association of an activity with the organizations that are responsible for its execution or its management. That kind of information can be represented with instances of .
the identifier or set of identifiers for the ActivityAssignment.

the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the ActivityAssignment.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the ActivityAssignment.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the meaning of the assignment/association.
Where applicable, the following values shall be used:
'input': the concepts represented by the items are inputs of the ;
'output': the concepts represented by the items result from the ;
'constraint': the concepts represented by the items influence the execution of the .
Presence of a gas tube may constrain the execution of drilling of a hole.

An ActivityMethodWorkRequestAssociation is an association between an and a . The associated serves as a recommended or non-recommended method to resolve the tasks specified in the . The associationType attribute characterizes the meaning of that association and the meaning of the with respect to the .

An ActivityRelationship is a relationship between two objects.
The activity required to complete a work order, may be decomposed into a series of activities. Their corresponding instances would be related using instances of the ActivityRelationship entity.
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the ActivityRelationship.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the ActivityRelationship.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class names shall be used:
'alternative': The business object defines a relationship where the related may be used alternatively instead of the relating ;
'decomposition': The business object defines a relationship where the related is one of potentially more sub-activities into which the relating is broken down;
'derivation': The business object defines a relationship where the related is derived from the relating ;
An that is controlled by a with 'manufacturing release' may be derived from (is based on) another controlled by another with 'design release'..
'exclusiveness': The business object defines a relationship where the relating and the related shall not have any overlap in time of execution;
'precedence': The business object defines a relationship where the related has higher priority than the relating ;
'sequence': The business object defines a relationship where the relating shall be completed before the related starts;
'simultaneity': The business object defines a relationship that establishes that both the relating and related are considered as occurring during the same time period or shall be performed together in order to ensure consistency and enhance efficiency.
one object of that is part of the relationship.
The relating usually identifies the , which is based on the definition of the related, for example, derived from or dependent on.
The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relationType.
the other object of that is part of the relationship.
The related usually identifies the , which is based on the definition of the relating.
The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relationType.
the related and the relating must be different.

The format of uniform resource locators is defined in IETF RFC 1738 [31]. URLs are used to identify world wide web sites, file transfer protocol (FTP) servers, etc.
A AlternatePartRelationship is a type of
where the relating part represents the base part and the related part represents the alternate part. It specifies that any version of the alternate part, may be used in place of any version of the base part, regardless of its usages and of its versions. The relationship established by the AlternatePartRelationship is not symmetric: if part B is an alternate part for part A, part A is not implied to be an alternate part for part B.
If a part is an alternate for another part, it is understood that there is no interest in keeping track of which part, the base or any alternates specified, is used as a particular instance of the base part within a part structure
An organization may track design changes for a base part, and establish effectivity conditions for the use of that base part in various assemblies to be manufactured. The use of an alternate part implies that an organization does not specify any particular version of the alternate part nor establish effectivities relating to it
An AlternatePartRelationship may relate parts of any kind, provided both related
objects identify parts of the same part category.
An AlternatePartRelationship for which the base part is an assembly involves that the entire part structure of the alternate part may be used in place of the base part and its part structure.
This concept usually refers to form, fit, function, and quality. Additional properties such as performance, noise, endurance, or reliability may also be considered as a prerequisite for the replacement
Two bolts of the same size are parts. One bolt has a square head and the other has a hexagonal head. The two bolts are considered equivalent with respect to form, fit, and function: they both have sufficiently close physical shape, they take up the same space when used, and they both serve to fasten two things together. Thus, one of these two bolts could be considered to be an alternate part for the other bolt.
The following additional data can be assigned to an AlternatePartRelationship: , , , , , and .
the word or set of words describing the requirements that are covered by both the base part and the alternate part and therefore are the basis for the statement regarding the capability of replacing the base part by the alternate part.
Additional properties such as performance, noise, endurance, or reliability may also be considered as a prerequisite for the replacement in addition to form, fit, function, and quality.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the inherited attribute relationType. The value of relationType shall be 'alternate'.
The combination of the related part and the relating part shall be unique.
An AlternativeSolution is an object that identifies one of potentially many mutually exclusive implementations of a ; the
may be classified as functional or physical.
An AlternativeSolution may refer directly to the object to be implemented or to another AlternativeSolution object. In the latter case it serves as a refinement of the referenced AlternativeSolution.
An AlternativeSolution may specify (through with attribute
having the values 'functionality' or 'realization') a set of objects that jointly form this implementation.
An AlternativeSolution may be one of its specializations , , or .

the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:
'decomposition': The related object is one of potentially more components of the relating . This relation type shall only be used for relating and related objects of the same type;
'functionality': The related object is an element of the functional structure of the relating object;
The
'heat dissipation' may be considered as one of the functionalities to be fulfilled by any . for the ; the 'braking system'.
'realization': The related is a means for fulfilling, either partially or fully, the requirements identified by the relating . This relation type shall only be used for relating and related objects of different types;
'specialization': The related object fulfils the requirements of the relating in a more specific way than defined for the relating . This relation type shall only be used for relating and related objects of the same type.
the first of the two
objects related by the AlternativeSolutionRelationship.

A ApplicationDomain is an identification of the applications for which an object may be relevant.
the proxies of the ApplicationDomain.
The sameAs shall be unique. Where applicable the following values shall be used:
'assembly study': The object may be relevant for an assembly study;
'digital mock-up': The object may be relevant for digital mock-up;
'electrical design': The object may be relevant for the electrical design;
'mechanical design': The object may be relevant for the mechanical design;
'preliminary design': The object may be relevant for the preliminary design;
'process planning': The object may be relevant for the process planning;
'product support': The object may be relevant for the product support;
'not specific': The object is considered as not specific of any application domain.
An Approval is a judgement and formal confirmation of the quality of those product or activity data that are subject of the Approval. An Approval represents a statement made by technical personnel or management personnel whether certain requirements are met. The absence of approval information does not imply any approval status by default.
the identifier or set of identifiers for the Approval.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in Fundamental concepts and assumptions.
the classifications of the Approval.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the point in time when the Approval actually became valid. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
In cases, where more than one person or organization has to sign off on the Approval, usually the last sign-off date corresponds to the date specified as the actualDate.
the personnel responsible for the Approval and the dates of the Approval. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the point in time when the Approval is or was supposed to be performed. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the text that completes the information provided within the status attribute, specifying the reason or goal of the Approval. 'released for production' or 'preliminary design completed' are approval purposes.
Where applicable, the following values may be used:
'disposition': The referenced object is approved for series production;
'equipment order': The referenced object has reached a status in which changes are subject to a defined change process and tools and other equipment required for production may be ordered;
'planning': The referenced object is technically complete and has reached a status sufficiently stable so that other designs may be based on it.
the objects for which the Approval is valid. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
a user interpretable designation of the level of acceptance of the object that the Approval is assigned to, in the context of the specified purpose.
The approval purposes are defined within a given life cycle stage view and are typically dependent upon the approval cycles within an individual business process. For each defined purpose, generally there is a defined sequence of values for the status, usually leading towards the status 'approved' indicating achievement of the particular purpose. Approval status values may be 'in progress', 'approved', 'approved with comments' and 'not approved'.

An AssemblyJoint is the representation of the result of the process that establishes physical connectivity between shape elements of two components in an assembly.
Figure 1 illustrates the roles assigned to items in an assembly by a designer in constructing a member of AssemblyJoint.
Assembly joint
AssemblyJoint provides information necessary to extract a network description of a design from the assembly model. Once extracted, the description may be compared to the original requirements.
AssemblyJoint provides critical information necessary to evaluate the appropriateness of the two shapes related by AssemblyJoint to their use in the assembly, given the process used for the joint.
AssemblyJoint provides critical information necessary to evaluate the appropriateness of the relative position of the two shapes related by AssemblyJoint, given the process used for the joint, and the technology used for each of the associated components, including related tolerances.

A BeveledSheetRepresentation is a type of that has a significant thickness, and whose edge is beveled at a constant angle around its entire perimeter. It is an extension of the concept of a thin sheet to products, such as honeycomb core, that have significant thickness but can be formed to mate with a curved surface.

A BoundaryCurveRepresentation is a set of curves that define the sheet edge. These curves define a closed area but are not necessarily restrained topologically. A CartesianPoint is a type of . A CartesianPoint is a point that is defined by its coordinates in a rectangular Cartesian coordinate system.

A CentreOfMass is a type of
that is the centre of the mass of a body. The relative position of the CentreOfMass within the body is an invariant datum relative to rotation and translation. The CentreOfMass is a characteristic of a part, not its shape.
If a shape representation is present, the CentreOfMass is usually derivable from the shape representation. However, as a characteristic of a part, it may be pre-defined in order to reflect a requirement.
In order to convey the information about the actual centre of mass of a geometric model, the use of
with value 'centroid' for its attribute
is appropriate.

A CircularPath is a type of
that describes a direction of travel along a circular arc that is defined by the start position, the end position and an intermediate position to pass through between the start and end position. While doing so a link that is traversing along the path is continuously rotating from the start orientation to the end orientation. The path shall be traversed in linear speed, which is given by the previous time or parameter value and the new time or parameter value.
an intermediate through which the CircularPath passes.
A Class is a classification of an object which characterizes all objects of the same kind; such a classification is independent from the application of the classified object. A fastener with subclasses, such as fastener with 2 or 3 fixture holes, a bracket with subclasses, e.g., with 90 or 100 degrees bending angle, or screws with subclasses such as metal screws or machine screws are examples for Class.
For facilitating an effective part retrieval for slotted screws, several Class objects may be defined to classify screws:
A Class *1 with description 'slotted screws' and three subclasses with the descriptions *2: 'slotted cheese head screws - product grade A', *3: 'slotted pan head screws - product grade A', and *4: 'slotted countersunk flat head screws - product grade A'.
Each of the Class objects is based on a Class that further defines where the definition of the Class comes from. For Class *1 this is a company internal for 'screw classes'. For the other Class objects these are ISO standardized objects, namely for *2 'ISO 1207', for *3 'ISO 1580', and for *4 'ISO 2010'.
The Class objects may be characterized further by objects. According to ISO 1207, the Class *2 has the attributes *11 with id 'd' and description 'thread', *12 with id 'l' and description 'nominal length', *13 with id 'mechanical properties' and description 'property class', etc. The possible values 'M1.6', 'M2', ..., 'M10' for *11 may be defined as objects in a set of the attribute . The according specification is given as of the AO . The refer as their definition to a with the 'nominal metric thread diameter'.
To identify the designation 'Cheese head screw ISO 1207 - M5 x 20 x 4.8', a subclass of Class *2 is defined with the same description 'slotted cheese head screws ISO 1207 -M5 x 20 x 4.8' but with the values for Class_attribute corresponding to *11 restricted to 'M5' only, i.e., to get just the M5 screws, corresponding to *12 restricted to value '20' only, and corresponding to *13 restricted to value '4.8' only (for steel according to ISO 898-1 [7]).
the identifier or set of identifiers for the Class.

A CompositeAssembly is a type of that is made of multiple materials that are bonded together. A CompositeAssembly may be made from any combination of materials. A completed CompositeAssembly need not be a rigid shape. A CompositeAssembly may also be used as a composite part.

A CompositeAssemblySequenceDefinition is a single unique sequence or layer within a . The sequence or layer contains one or more constituent parts. When more than one constituent part resides in the same sequence or layer, the constituents must not overlap.
If constituents do overlap they must be put on separate sequence or layers.
specifies the collection of components in a single unique sequence or layer in a part. The componentsInSequence shall be a collection of one or more of the types.

A CompositeSheetRepresentation is a type of that defines a sheet product. A sheet product is a product whose thickness is constant and small in comparison to its length and width. Most sheet products will conform to the surface on which they are placed. The shape of a sheet product can be represented in a 3-dimensional model of the actual shape, as a shape projected onto the layup surface, or as a shape projected into a 2-dimensional plane. A typical composite sheet is 0.1 to 0.4 millimeters thick while its length and width are much greater than 25 millimeters. A CompositeSheetRepresentation may be one of the following:
,
.

of . The following values shall be used:
'exception': No inheritance scheme is applicable and all required configuration information must be attached locally at the business object. The value indicates that the configuration information may be inconsistent to the structural levels above it or that it is, on purpose, contradictory to it. Such a condition implies that an inheritance scheme shall not continue beyond this point in the product structure tree
A situation where the inheritanceType 'exception' is applicable is a technical solution released for one particular customer without support in higher structure levels.
'inherited': A scheme for inheritance of configuration information applies. The complete configuration information shall be collected from the different levels in the structure by evaluation of results. The results shall be evaluated using the logical AND to combine configuration information starting at the referenced configuredElement and using the logical OR to combine alternatives. In addition, this evaluation shall consider related effectivity information. 'inherited' only applies for objects for which the same value of configurationType is defined;
The following figure shows how inheritance is applied along the tree of a product structure.
Inheritance along product structure tree
The complete configuration information of a
can be obtained by adding any such information to
objects which are linked through
objects and
attributes respectively. Whenever more than one higher level instance is present, the current information available is branched in as many branches as instances are present. For example, the total configuration information for the
given in the figure above could be expressed as follows: (C0.0 AND C1.0 AND C2.0) OR (C0.0 AND C1.1 AND C2.1) OR (C0.0 AND C1.1 AND C2.2).
'local': No inheritance scheme is applicable and all required configuration information must be attached locally at the business object. Nevertheless, any potentially inherited configuration information of a higher level shall be consistent, i.e., it shall be a subset of the locally defined configuration information.

A ContentProperty is the specification of characteristics precising the content of a or of a . At least one of the optional attributes shall be specified for each instance of this object. In the case where a ContentProperty is referred by a , the characteristics apply to all individual objects, whereas in the case where it is referred by a , the characteristics apply on an individual basis.

'rough 3d shape': three-dimensional shape model without edge rounds and fillets;

the kind or kinds of geometry that an object contains. Where applicable the following values shall be used:
'3D wireframe model': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in wireframe representation;
'2D shape': The document contains a two-dimensional shape model or contours only;
'surface model': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in surface representation;
'closed volume': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in closed body topological surface representation;
'solid model': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in advanced boundary representation;
'solid and surface model': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in surface and advanced boundary representation;
'assembly': The document contains an assembly structure with reference to the assembled components and their transformation matrices;
'assembly with mating elements': The document contains an assembly structure including the mating components only, such as screws or rivets, with exact positioning information. This assembly representation is intended to be overlayed with the assembly structure for the main components;
'2D drawing': The document contains a technical drawing without three-dimensional shape representation;
'drawing derived from 3D data': The document contains a technical drawing that has been derived from a three-dimensional shape model;
'drawing related to 3D data': The document contains a technical drawing that visualizes a three-dimensional shape model and possibly establishes associative left to the three-dimensional shape model.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the language or languages which are used in the characterized objects.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A DateAndPersonAssignment is an object that associates a
with product data. This assignment provides additional information for the associated object. The provision of such data through this assignment has an organizational character whereas some objects require the same kind of data in order to be semantically complete. This assignment shall not be used to associate the corresponding organizational data with an object whose attributes are referencing the organizational data directly. An example for the requirement stated is that there shall not exist a DateAndPersonAssignment with a role of 'requestor' that refers to a , since this object refers directly to in that role.
In the context of the object DateAndPersonAssignment, the expression 'referenced object' means 'a concept that is conveyed within one of the instances referred to by the attribute assignedTo and not one of the instances referred to by this attribute.
If applied to an instance of with role 'creation', the DateAndPersonAssignment specifies the creation date of the part, tool, or raw material as a new object in the activity domain of the organization, and not the creation date of the instance of in the product management system of the organization.

'creation': The assignment specifies that the referenced object has been created by the given person or organization at the given date and time;
'update': The assignment specifies that the referenced object has been altered by the given person or organization at the given date and time.

A DatedEffectivity is a type of
for which the domain of applicability is defined as an interval of time, bounded by dates or events. Especially at planning stage it may be useful to bound a DatedEffectivity period by objects.
Depending on whether the startDefinition and/or endDefinition are specified, the actual domain of time defined by a DatedEffectivity is one of the following:
if both are specified: the time interval between the start and end date or event;
if only startDefinition is specified: the open time interval that starts at the start date or event, that is, the effectivity or ineffectivity is endless; or
if only endDefinition is specified: the open time interval that ends at the end date or event, that is, the beginning of the effectivity or ineffectivity is unspecified.
The start date or event may be omitted to indicate the best-before date of, for example, motor oil or a first aid kit.
If the endDefinition identifies a point in time that comes before the startDefinition, the actual domain of effectivity is empty.
the or
that defines the upper bound of the interval of applicability. The value of this attribute need not be specified. If the value for this attribute is not specified, the interval of applicability has no upper bound.
the or that defines the lower bound of the interval of applicability. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A DrapedOrientationAngle is a type of that defines a position and direction at a point within a part.
The warp direction of a fabric shall be placed in the specified direction prior to draping over the part. Once the fabric has been draped, the orientation angle at any given point must be derived from the draped shape of the fabric. The DrapedOrientationAngle will change in the part if the surface of the part has complex curvature.

An EdgeZoneShape is a type of that depicts the outline of a zone or area of a part.
An EdgeZoneShape might not be a distinguishable physical edge. It could be where a smooth transition in thickness of the part starts or stops.
specifies the geometry that defines the shape of the zone. The boundary shall be one of the entities.
An Effectivity is an identification of the valid use of an aspect of product data tracked by date, event, serial number or lot size.
An instance of Effectivity may define a period or a part of ineffectivity, i.e., of invalid use, if it is referred to by an instance of with set to 'false'.
An Effectivity may 'inherit' its interval from another Effectivity through an with
'inheritance'. If a 'start' and no 'end' is specified, the period is then added to 'start' in order to get the actual 'end' of the effectivity or ineffectivity.
the identifier or set of identifiers for the Effectivity.

The Effectivity of the same part may be different in the various production sites of a car manufacturer.
As Effectivity is in most cases organization dependent, it is recommended always to populate the concernedOrganizations attribute.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the life cycle stage for which the Effectivity is valid. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

'actual': The actual period during which the assignedEffectivity lasted;

Where applicable, the following class names shall be used:
'actualization': The relationship specifies that the relating identifies a predicted or planned event and the related identifies the point in time when that event actually occurred. This relationship is valid if the attribute of the relating is not specified and the attribute of the related is specified, or, if both these attributes are specified and equal;
'exclusiveness': The relationship specifies that the relating and the related
shall not have any overlap during their duration;
'sequence': The relationship specifies that the relating shall be completed before the related starts;
'simultaneity': The relationship specifies that both the relating and related are considered as occurring during the same time period or shall be performed together in order to ensure consistency and enhance efficiency.
The criteria for 'simultaneity' and in particular the allowed delay between two events declared simultaneous, are user-dependent.

The angular accuracy value can be used to determine the accuracy range for tangent continuous curve or surface connections.

Terms surrounded by the FORMULA symbols represent the absolute values of these terms.

A FilamentLaminate is a type of that is a bonded material of two or more bundles of filament construction. The FilamentLaminate defines a volume to fill with filament assemblies.
The shape of a FilamentLaminate may be defined by a cross section and a length.
When a FilamentLaminate is made from a , it usually refers to individual tows, yarns, and rovings. These volumes can be as simple as the cross section and length of a radius filler to as complex as a filament wound vessel. FilamentLaminates that are made by pulling and forming processes, called pultrusions, may use a tape form of FilamentAssembly.
The difference between a ply and a FilamentLaminate, when referencing a , is that a ply describes a constant thickness area to be filled by a and a FilamentLaminate describes a general volume to be filled by a . Pultruded shapes, radius fillers, and filament wound structure are types of FilamentLaminate (see following figure).
Filament laminate
specifies the stock that the FilamentLaminate is made from. The FilamentLaminate is in the form of a tow, yarn or roving, and sometimes tape.
specifies the geometry that defines the cross-sectional area of a FilamentLaminate. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
The stock material shall be of type filament assembly.

A FinalSolution is a type of
and is a set of additional sensual characteristics that can be applied to a that represents a neutral part in order to complete its definition.
In the case of a car body, the neutral parts are parts without paint; the final parts are the parts with paint. In the case of a seat, the neutral part is the seat with unspecified cover material; the final part may be the seat covered with red leather.
A FinalSolution may be associated with a that represents the finalized part through a .
The information common to all final solutions based on the same neutral part may identified by use of instances of .

the text string that describes the level of completion between the neutral part and the final part.
'final for shipping overseas', 'final for transport by truck', or 'final for sale' are examples for status.

The character set in ISO 646 is identical to the character set commonly known as ASCII

A FunctionalBreakdown is a type of
that identifies a partitioning of a product into a structured set of objects that are classified to be functional objects. A FunctionalBreakdown is a view of the functions of a product by means of parent-child relationships. Not all functions of the product need to be included in a FunctionalBreakdown.
Parent-child relationships are represented by objects.
A FunctionalBreakdown may provide a decomposition of an aircraft in terms of high-level functional processes, such as flight, taxiing and at rest, all the way down to low-level processes such as detect on board fuel level, move tail rudder and provide standard tow attachment point.

A GeneralShapeDependentProperty is a type of
that defines a user-defined characteristic of an object. The specified by a GeneralShapeDependentProperty is derived from geometry.
The GeneralShapeDependentProperty may be used for the purpose of validation of geometric models. If a geometry model is exchanged between two partners, the calculation of various properties of the bodies, such as centre of mass, overall surface, or overall volume, is performed by originator and recipient. When comparing these set of values, the existence of deficiencies in the received model can be easily detected.
the type of characteristic that is specified for an object. The following values shall be used:
'centroid': The identifies the centre point of the mass of a body. The relative position of this point within the body is an invariant datum relative to rotation and translation.; An example, where the use of this GeneralShapeDependentProperty with propertyType 'centroid' is used instead of the object , is the following: sometimes the GeneralShapeDependentProperty is calculated by some system at some point of time. But there are cases where the information, e.g., the GeneralShapeDependentProperty of a die, is transferred into a following stage, e.g., in order to perform a feasibility check, where there is only a simplified shape representation that does not allow to calculate the exact GeneralShapeDependentProperty. Yet, in this stage the information about the GeneralShapeDependentProperty is needed in order to check whether the transport of a die with a crane is feasible.
'surface area': The specifies the overall surface of the bodies contained in the referenced shape.;
'volume': The specifies the overall volume of the bodies contained in the referenced shape.
the value that is given for a particular characteristic.
the unit in which the GeneralShapeDependentProperty is expressed. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A GeometricCoordinateSpace is a representation of a coordinate space in which geometric elements may be defined. It is either two-dimensional or three-dimensional. In the case where geometric elements are defined in the GeometricCoordinateSpace, there shall be at least two units specified, the length unit and the plane angle unit. The same length unit is applied to each coordinate direction. Only one unit of a kind shall be specified. The value of this attribute need not be specified only if the GeometricCoordinateSpace belongs to an .
If elements with different units are required, they have to be separated into different models with their own GeometricCoordinateSpace.
A length measure unit measured in inches and an angle measure unit measured in degrees are examples for two members of the attribute units assigned to the same GeometricCoordinateSpace.
The length unit millimetre and the angle unit radian are examples of units of a GeometricCoordinateSpace.
the dimensionality of the GeometricCoordinateSpace shall be greater than 0.

An IndividualPart is the identification of an individual artefact that has been made or is planned to be made. It is a collector of data common to all versions of the IndividualPart.
Versions () of IndividualPart are used to represent whether an individual artefact is planned to be made or has already been made.
Where physical parts are being represented, a IndividualPart represents the planned or actual physical realization of a part.
It is likely, but not essential, that the artefact, was or will be made from a part design. The part design will be represented by a which will be related to the IndividualPart by .
Many physical parts may be produced from a given design. A single may lead to many IndividualPart objects.
The design of a personal computer is represented by a .
The personal computer with a serial number on a persons desk is represented by an .
The personal computer that has been ordered, allocated a serial number for manufacturing planning, but not yet manufactured, is represented by a . An actual personal computer, also represented by a may be linked to the planed personal computer by a object.

A InformationRight is a definition of what may or may not be done with an item of information in the sense of legal rights and obligations. is an InformationRight. For the purposes of developing a new system, details of government furnished equipment may be made available to a particular project team. The team may copy and use the information internally, but may not pass it on, either to a third part, or to another team, and must destroy the information at the end of the contract.

The description of the right states that copying is permitted within the project team only, whereas the restriction notes the additional constraint that the information must be destroyed at the end of the project.
An InformationUsageRight is an application an to a particular usage context.
One view of the distinction between an and an InformationUsageRight is that the represents a standard clause in a contract, whereas an InformationUsageRight represents the fact that the clause is used in a particular contract.
The context for the usage can be defined through the contract which defines the right, the organization that grants the right, the person or organization which is granted the right, and any dates such as the starting or ending dates for the right. The meaning of each association is identified through the roles of the assignments, and these are defined through reference data.
The of an InformationUsageRight carries the meaning that the right is granted to all information items in the relevant context, as opposed to the approval of an which is limited to particular items.
InformationUsageRight provides a mechanism for recording significant rights within a product database. The legal significance of the presence or absence of a right is outside the scope of this part of ISO 10303.
the identifier or set of identifiers for the InformationUsageRight.

A InformationUsageRightAssignment is an assignment of a particular usage right to a set of items.
If an is applied to this entity, it carries the meaning that the particular set of items is approved for the given usage. This approval generally indicates that the approval is exceptional, for example, where the information belongs to another project, and that project agrees to share some particular items of information. There is a further implication that the set of entities should not be changed once the approval is given.

A LaminateTable is a type of . A LaminateTable defines the internal constituents or structural makeup of an overall part or a particular zone, area, or point on the part. A LaminateTable may be either a , a or a .
There are two functions provided by a LaminateTable. The first is to describe the order in which the physical constituents of a laminate are assembled. This is called a or . The second is to describe the structural makeup of a particular zone, area, or point within a laminate. This is called a .
specifies the used to define the lamination or layers. The layers or lamination are defined to start from the surface and to be laminated or layered in the specified direction and order.

A MatingDefinition is a type of . It is a view of a , defining the physical connection of two or more
objects. It includes technical information about the kind of connection. This information is independent from the hierarchical assembly structure.
the kind of mating, that is, how the items shall be mated together. Where applicable the following values shall be used:
'bolted joint': Attachment of two or more items that are screwed together using screws, bolt nuts, and washers;
'brazing': Attachment of two or more items established by soldering or brazing;
'clasping': Attachment of two or more items established by using a clamp at one common outer border;
'clinching': Attachment of two or more items established by pressing these items together and stamping texture at the point of contact;
'clipping': Attachment of two or more items established by a clip ( e.g. fixing the inner door panel at the inner door plate);
'doweling': Attachment of two or more items using a pin that is fit into each of each part by pressing;
'flanging': Attachment of two or more items by crimping a projected length of one part over the edge of the other part;
'foam injection': Attachment of two or more items where foam is injected into a cavity to establish the connection;
'gluing': Attachment of two items established by adhesion material;
'laser-welding': Attachment of two or more items that are welded together using a laser technique;
'press fit': Attachment of two or more items obtained by forces resulting from the selected size tolerances;
'riveting': Attachment of two or more items that are riveted together at a certain spot using a rivet;
'sewing': Attachment of two or more items that are sewn together;
Upholstering cloth is sewn together to form a seat pillow.
'spot welding': Attachment of two or more items that are welded together at a certain welding spot;
'stapling': Attachment of two or more items at a certain spot using a nail or a wire stitch to establish the connection;
'welding': Attachment of two or more items by welding together with one weld bead.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.

that reference a MatingDefinition instance as values of their attributes with name relating.

An OrganizationOrPersonInOrganizationAssignment is an object that associates an or a with product data. This assignment provides additional information for the associated object. The provision of such data through this assignment has an organizational character whereas some objects require the same kind of data in order to be semantically complete. This assignment shall not be used to associate the corresponding organizational data with an object whose attributes are referencing the organizational data directly. The OrganizationOrPersonInOrganizationAssignment shall not be used for the purpose of specifying a relationship between two objects, e.g., a succession in organizational responsibility. For these purposes, shall be used.
the identifier or set of identifiers for the OrganizationOrPersonInOrganizationAssignment.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in Fundamental concepts and assumptions.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

specifies the responsibility of the assigned or with respect to the object that it is applied to. Where applicable the following values shall be used:
'author': The referenced object has been created by the assigned or . The author holds the copyright;
'classification officer': The assigned or is formally responsible for the classification of the referenced object;
'creator': The referenced object has been created by the assigned or ;
'custodian': The assigned or is responsible for the existence and integrity of the referenced object;
'customer': The assigned or acts as a purchaser or consumer of the referenced object;
'design supplier': The assigned or is the one who delivers the data describing the referenced object; The 'design supplier' may be a design by means of a three-dimensional model or a drawing.
'editor': One or more attributes have been modified by the assigned or ;
'id owner': The assigned or is the one responsible for the designation of an identifier;
'location': The assigned is the place where the referenced object can be found or where it takes place;
'manufacturer': The assigned or is the one who produces the actual (physical) object;
'owner': The assigned or owns the referenced object, and has final say over its disposition and any changes to it;
'read access': The assigned or neither has the right to modify any attributes of the referenced object, nor to modify, create or delete objects that are attached directly or indirectly to the referenced object;
'supplier': The assigned or is the one who delivers the actual (physical) object (e.g., a dealer);
'wholesaler': The assigned or is the one who is in the sales chain between the manufacturer and the supplier;
'write access': The assigned or has the right to modify the attributes of the referenced object, as well as to modify, create, or delete objects that are attached directly or indirectly to the referenced object.
specifies the concerned or the .
the objects to which the OrganizationOrPersonInOrganizationAssignment is assigned.

A Part is a identification of definition of a part. It collects the definitional information of the versions of a part. A Part shall always be categorized as 'piece part', 'product', 'software', 'tool', or 'raw material' using a .
A Part does not represent an actual physical object of the real world.
A Part may be either a single piece part, an assembly of arbitrary complexity, a raw material, or a tool.
In the context of cars, a Part may be the car as a whole, the assembly of the engine, the car body, a fender, the side window glass, grease, or a stamping die.
In the context of aeroplanes, a Part may be the air plane as a whole, the assembly of the engine, the body of the air plane, a fender, the side window glass, grease, or a stamping die.
A Part is identified by an organization. The definition of the domain of uniqueness and the mechanism for guaranteeing the uniqueness of Part id are outside the scope of this capability.
A Part may have zero or more versions. Versions of a Part are represented by the entity .

A PathSegment is a portion of a complete kinematic path and describes the movement of a link from a previous position and orientation to a new position and orientation in space. A PathSegment is either a , a or a .
Linear and circular types of paths are continuous motions, point-to-point paths are discontinuous motions.
the to which the parameters of the PathSegment refer. It is the location and orientation of the end-point of the PathSegment.
The placementEnd is specified to enable evaluation by manufacturing systems, which use the information to determine various machining parameters.
the parameter value that represents the end location of a travel along the PathSegment.
the type of smoothness of the motion along the path. The following values shall be used:
'cont same gradient': the motion occurs continuously with a constant gradient;
'cont same gradient same curvature': gradient and curvature of the motion are constant;
'continuous': the motion is continuous;
'discontinuous': the motion is interrupted.
For PathSegment objects of types or
the value of transition shall be 'continuous'.
A PercentageLaminateTable is a type of that defines the percentage of the total thickness within a zone or point that each uniquely oriented constituent stock material makes up.
For a simple laminate just made out of plies (), a PercentageLaminateTable is used to capture the percentages of different fiber orientations within the zone based on the overall thickness of the zone. An example would be 40% 0 degree fibers, 30% 90 degree fibers, 15% +45 degree fibers, and 15% -45 degree fibers. The sum of the percents (%) have to equal 100. The sum of must equal 100.
specifies the set of that defines the makeup of the zone. There shall exist one or more for the PercentageLaminateTable.
specifies the thickness or depth of the part at the area defined by the PercentageLaminateTable.
A PercentagePly is an idealization of a ply that represents a portion (percentage) of the thickness of a with a particular fiber orientation (if required) and material type. This represents a way to relate anisotropic material properties to the varied orientations that exist in a composite part. A PercentagePly always corresponds to the area within the zone of the LaminateTable of which it is a portion.
specifies the structural makeup of the zone represented by the PercentagePly. A shall not be used as makeupAndProperties for a PercentagePly. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
specifies the for the zone represented by the PercentagePly.
specifies the angle giving the material direction (warp direction of a fabric) in a local coordinate system ().The value of this attribute need not be specified.
specifies the amount of volume the PercentagePly occupies relative to the total volume of the .

A PhysicalBreakdown is a type of
that identifies a partitioning of a product into a set of objects that are classified to be physical objects. A PhysicalBreakdown is a view of the constituents of a product by means of parent-child relationships. Not all constituents of the product need to be included in a PhysicalBreakdown.
Parent-child relationships are represented by objects.
A PhysicalBreakdown may provide a decomposition of an automobile in terms such as body, roof, bonnet, bumpers. Such a breakdown may be differerent from and orthogonal to a parts decomposition.

A PlannedCharacteristic may be used as basis for the evaluation of a product against its requirements by using .

A Ply is a type of that defines one of the layers of constant thickness material that make up a composite part. A Ply is a contiguous structure with a defined boundary that is made of one or more objects (see following figure).
A Ply may be a sheet pre-impregnated with resin material or a single-pass in a filament winding. Ply pieces that comprise a Ply must be of the same constant thickness material and fiber orientation (if fiber orientation is required). A Ply can also be the application of an isotropic material of constant thickness to an area. A Ply may not necessarily be a physical piece of material but an idealization of material in a zone that shares common fiber orientation and boundary.
The boundary of a Ply defines the edge of the material used to make the Ply, and includes an outer boundary and, if required, inner boundaries.
Ply
specifies the that the Ply is made of.
specifies the list of objects that make up the Ply. There shall exist one or more s for the Ply. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
specifies the direction of the reinforcement fibers within a Ply. For materials with multiple orientations of fibers, orientation shall correspond to the warp direction of the material.
specifies the thickness that the Ply will contribute to part thickness after curing. The plyThickness is constant over the whole area of the Ply.
specifies the geometric representation for the Ply (). The value of this attribute need not be specified.
plyThickness value must be superior or equal to 0.
the unit name of the weight attribute, inherited from ConstitentPart, must be 'length'.
A PlyLaminate is a type of that is formed by two or more objects that mate with each other. The plies have unique orientation and shape within the PlyLaminate.
Examples of PlyLaminate shape include angle, cap, flat, general contour, simple contour, complex contour, channel, etc. (see following figure).
Ply laminate
specifies the ordered list of the sets that make up the PlyLaminate.
specifies the overall geometric representation of the PlyLaminate such as the edge of the PlyLaminate and any internal cutouts. The shape shall be one of the entities. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
A PlyLaminateSequenceDefinition is a type of that is an illustration of a single unique sequence or layer within a . The sequence or layer contains one or more plies.
When more than one ply resides in the same sequence or layer, the plies must not overlap. If plies do overlap they must be put on separate sequence or layers.
specifies the set of that are laminated at the sequence. There shall exist one or more for the PlyLaminateSequenceDefinition.
A PlyLaminateTable is a type of that provides an ordered list of objects. The ordered list provides basic placement position within the laminate (see following figure).
The valid components of a PlyLaminateTable are plies only.
The PlyLaminateTable is only valid to describe a .
Ply laminate table
specifies an ordered list of sets that make up the . There shall be not less than two for the PlyLaminateTable.
A PlyOrientationAngle is an entitie that defines a particular direction within a . The direction is defined in the coordinate axis of a . The measurement is in degrees between -90 and +90. A PlyOrientationAngle may be one either a or a .
For materials with multiple fiber orientations, the direction shall correspond to the warp direction of the material. Warp fibers are the primary load carrying fibers within a fabric material.
In the design of a particular composite part, a finite set of PlyOrientationAngle values are established for use. An example of a set of commonly used PlyOrientationAngle is (0, 90, +45, -45).
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the PlyOrientationAngle.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
specifies the , , or a to serve as a reference for ply orientation. The angleReference shall be one of the entities for the PlyOrientationAngle.
specifies the direction of the fiber within the ply.
specifies the coordinate axis in which the fiberDirection is defined.
A PlyPiece is a type of . It is a single portion of a that may be combined with other ply pieces on the same layer to make up the . A PlyPiece has the same material and orientation direction as defined for the of which it is a portion.
may be too small to fully cover the area of a . In this case the application may allow two or more pieces to be used. Tape strips are a typical example of PlyPieces that are grouped together to fill a .
specifies the geometric representation of the PlyPiece. The shape shall be a . The shape need not be specified for a particular PlyPiece.
specifies whether or not the material warp surface is away from the basis surface, when the value of this attribute is set to true or false respectively. Material warp surface is the side of the material where the majority of the fibers are located.
A PlyShape is the association of a geometric representation to define the shape of a .
specifies the shape representation that the PlyShape is derived from or that is used as its basis of definition. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the geometric representation used for the PlyShape. The definingModel shall be one of the entities.
A Point is a type of . A Point is a location in a Cartesian coordinate space.
A PointToPointPath is a type of
definition of a kinematic path by means of frames that shall be traversed. It does not include a prescribed interpolation.
The interpolation is left to the software that uses the data.
A PointToPointPath describes a discontinuous motion, which is indicated by the inherited attribute with the value 'discontinuous'.
A PointZoneShape is a type of that specifies a point on the surface of a part. It also specifies the singular volume a piercing line would make as it traveled through the part, normal to the part's surface at the point.
specifies the that defines the position of the local pierced point of the PointZoneShape.

A ProcessedCore is a type of that is the central component of a sandwich construction to which faces or skins are attached. The primary structural purpose of ProcessedCore is the transfer of shear loads between the faces or skins. ProcessedCore is that has been machined, formed, stabilized and/or bonded together (see following figure ). A core may have a potting compound or adhesive applied to it to make it more rigid and/or provide solid attachment points.
Processed core
specifies the list of ply material such as stabilizer, potting compound, and adhesive,applied to a ProcessedCore. The identifies the area where the addedMaterial is applied. There sall exist zero or more Ply for the ProcessedCore. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
identifies the ribbon direction of the honeycomb core.
specifies a ProcessedCore that has another process performed on it. This is two or more ProcessedCore objects that are being assembled. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
specifies the that is processed to get the ProcessedCore configuration. The types of processes include machining, forming, stabilizing, and bonding.
specifies the geometric representation for the ProcessedCore. The shape shall be one of the entities. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
The in madeFromStock shall be STOCK_CORE.
A ProcessOperationDefinition is a specification of an activity that may be included in a . A ProcessOperationDefinition characterizes a manufacturing or control operation.
ProcessOperationDefinition as well as
may be associated with organizational data using, e.g., . The reason for having these data available for both types of objects is the requirement to associate ProcessOperationDefinition with organizational data in both a context independent and a context dependent way (the context is a particular ).
In the case where an instance of ProcessOperationDefinition is associated with, e.g., two
objects (e.g., as location), a context independent one and a context dependent one, the two locations need not be the same, but should be related in a way that the context dependent location should be a specialization of the context independent location e.g., a particular assembly line in a plant.

A ProductClass is an identification of a set of similar products to be offered to the market. ProductClass objects that are related to each other by a
do not inherit any characteristics from each other.
The following figure depicts a detail of an example of a structure that is built up by ProductClass and
objects.

the level of the ProductClass in a hierarchical structure of ProductClass objects.
A high level ProductClass (levelType = 'enterprise') may be used to define all
and
objects for all ProductClass objects of an enterprise with several brands and companies. A second level ProductClass (levelType = 'platform') may be used to group all products that are based on the same technical concept (platform); these products may belong to different brands. A third level ProductClass (levelType = 'car family') may be used to group all products that have a common base and a fixed set of characteristics (specification categories). A fourth level ProductClass (levelType = 'car type') may represent products that are offered to the market; this level of ProductClass may be defined by the marketing department. A set of specifications sufficient to produce the car is associated with its ProductClass. Within this association, a distinction is made between standard characteristics (e.g. number of doors) and options that have to be chosen (e.g., outside colour) or that may be chosen by the customer (e.g., radio).
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the text that identifies a marketing category of the ProductClass. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the words or group of words by which the market of the ProductClass is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A ProductConfiguration that is associated with a

The entity ProductConfiguration corresponds to the concept of configuration item defined, in some configuration management standards, as an item subject to configuration management.
A ProductConfiguration may represent a component of a contracted product, onto which severe safety rules apply and for which configuration management is therefore rigorously applied.

A Project is an identified program of work. It is a set of activities to create a product or service in accordance with specified resources and requirements.
A Project may be further characterized with planned or actual dates, allowed budget, activities or resources by attribute values of this business object or by assignments to other business objects.
For the development of a new car, a project is set up that is responsible for the development decisions, as well as for the accounting of the costs.

the point in time or the event when the execution of the Project is or was expected to start. The value of this attribute need not be specified. If present, there shall be exactly one object that defines the plannedStartDate for a Project.
the set of objects that are responsible for the Project. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A PromissoryAssemblyOccurrenceUsage is a type of . A PromissoryAssemblyOccurrenceUsage is a relationship between the occurrence of a constituent of an assembly and a view of the assembly itself. The relationship describes the intention to use the occurrence of a constituent of an assembly in an assembly. There may not be any geometric information provided for the constituent or the assembly that are associated by a PromissoryAssemblyOccurrenceUsage.
In early design stages, the PromissoryAssemblyOccurrenceUsage may be used to create preliminary BOMs for prototyping.
the inherited attribute relationType. The value of relationType shall be 'promissory assembly occurrence'.
A PromissoryAssemblyViewUsage is a type of . A PromissoryAssemblyViewUsage is a relationship between a view of an assembly constituent and a view of the assembly itself. The relationship describes the intention to use the view of an assembly constituent in an assembly. There may not be any geometric information provided for the view or the assembly that are associated by a PromissoryAssemblyViewUsage.
the inherited attribute relationType. The value of relationType shall be 'promissory assembly view'.

A Requirement is an essential characteristic, condition, or capability that shall be met or exceeded by a system or a component to satisfy a contract, standard, specification, or other formally imposed document.
The term "requirement" is used here in the sense that term is used in systems engineering and similar industrial domains.
There may be many versions of a Requirement through . There may also be more than one domain-specific view of a given (using the entity). The Requirement entity is simply a placeholder for holding a unique requirement. Most associations and properties could be defined at the Requirement, or level - that is in the context of a domain. A requirement may be identified as "NOx emissions requirement", and uniquely identified as "Req2".
Systems engineering tools and organizations may use differing identification mechanisms. Multiple identifiers may be managed in Requirement using the id attribute.
the identifier or set of identifiers for the Requirement.
This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in Fundamental concepts and assumptions.
the words or set of words by which the Requirement is known.
This attribute supports multiple names in different contexts as well as multi linguism.
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the proxies of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the versions of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
A RequirementAssignment is used to relate a (via or ) to data types representing the items (specified in ) which are affected by the requirement. A requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP" could be assigned to the data types which are used to represent the vehicle's engine.
the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementAssignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

the item (specified in ) which has the requirement assigned to it.
A RequirementCollectionRelationship is a type of . It identifies a collection relationship that is used to relate a parent (collection) requirement to its member requirements. This provides a method for collecting together a set of requirements and treating them as a single requirement, whilst still being able to refer to individual requirements.
the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

A RequirementSatisfactionAssertion is a relationship between an item (specified in ) and a requirement (via or the ), asserting that the item satisfies the identified requirement. A data type used to represent a vehicle's engine with a power output of 160BHP could be asserted to satisfy a requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP".

the item (specified in ) that satisfies the requirement.
the requirement (via the or the ) that is satisfied.

A RequirementSourceAssociation is a relationship between a requirement (via the or the ) and the data types representing the source (specified in ) of the requirement. A RequirementTracingRelationship is a type of . It identifies a tracing relationship. A requirement may trace to many other requirements and vice versa - this is achieved by creating multiple instances of the tracing relationship entity.
the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

A RequirementVersion is the identification of a particular version of a requirement.
This entity is used to record different versions of a requirement. In this case, the word "version" implies "revision" - that is a particular release of a requirement. A given requirement might have versions 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 and 2.0.

A RequirementView is a view of a requirement version relevant for one or more application domains. This view collects requirement data for specific engineering purposes. An engineer may have responsibility for collecting all requirements associated with the cooling of an engine - covering engine block, tubing, water pump, electric fan. Some requirements in a RequirementView might impact on different disciplines. Multiple RequirementView instances may be used to present different views of a given requirement for each discipline.
The definition of the requirement is represented by a set of definitional properties referenced from RequirementView.definitionalRepresentations. If more than one definitional property is provided each property shall be equivalent. Any other property that is associated with the RequirementView is assumed to be a non-defining property, such as an annotation etc. The requirement that the weight should be less than 4 Kgs can be represented by a string representation "weight must be 4Kg" and a numeric representation "4Kg" specified as a value with units.
the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementView. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A SelectedPartOccurrence is a type of
that is the identification of the occurrence of an object that is either defined as a ,
or as a
and whose quantity depends on certain constraints.
In a BOM where the exact amount of grease or glue can usually not be specified as a quantity, the specification of this grease or glue are examples for SelectedPartOccurrence objects.
To minimize the concentricity error of a wheel, weights are attached to the rim; this set of weights is a SelectedPartOccurrence. The quantity as well as the position of these weights depends on the concentricity behaviour of each particular wheel as manufactured and tested.
the constraint that has to be evaluated for the SelectedPartOccurrence.
'as required for balance' and 'as required for lubrication' are examples for a criterion.
the quantity of the part, tool or raw material foreseen as SelectedPartOccurrence. The quantity shall be of type or .
If the quantity is to be specified as a minimum and/or a maximum, then or may be used.
The quantity of engine oil used in a car may be in the range of 3.7 to 3.9 litres. This is expressed using
as the quantity.

If the endNumber is not specified, it is not foreseen that the SerialConfiguration ceases to be valid; i.e., the SerialConfiguration is expected to apply to all serial numbers greater than the serial start number for the product for whose characteristics the SerialConfiguration identifies a solution.
the serial number of that instance of the product that is the first instance for which the SerialConfiguration applies.

A ShapeDescriptionAssociation is a mechanism to relate the definition of a shape or of a portion of a shape with a geometric representation.
Through ShapeDescriptionAssociation, it is possible to associate objects with geometry defined in an external document; the same is possible through . The difference between the two possibilities is that in the case of ShapeDescriptionAssociation, it is the shape of the object that is assigned whereas may be used to assign other kinds of geometry.
